conclusion: We have an equilateral triangular frame ABC made of uniform resistance wires. The frame is placed perpendicular to a magnetic field (pointing into the page). Points A and B are connected to a power supply with constant voltage. We're told the Ampere force on segment AB is F. We need to find the magnitude of the resultant force on all three segments.

An equilateral triangular conductor frame ABC is placed in a magnetic field (indicated by the × symbols, which represent a magnetic field pointing into the page). Points A and B are connected to a power supply.

premise: Current flows directly from A to B along segment AB. Current also flows from A to C to B along segments AC and CB.
conclusion: Due to the conservation of current (Kirchhoff's current law), the current entering at point A must equal the current leaving at point B.

premise: Using the right-hand rule for the Lorentz force (F = IL×B) and the given force on segment AB.
conclusion: The force on segment AB is F, directed upward.

premise: Due to the equilateral structure and uniform resistance, the current through BC would be I/2. Length of BC = length of AB.
conclusion: The force on segment BC is F/2, directed upward and to the left at 60° from vertical.

premise: Current through CA is I/2 (same reasoning as for BC). Length of CA = length of AB.
conclusion: The force on segment CA is F/2, directed upward and to the right at 60° from vertical.

premise: The horizontal components of the forces on BC and CA will cancel each other out due to symmetry.
conclusion: The resultant force is purely vertical.

premise: Vertical component of force on AB = F. Vertical component of force on BC = F(√3/4). Vertical component of force on CA = F(√3/4).
conclusion: Total vertical component = F + F(√3/4) + F(√3/4) = F(1 + √3/2).

premise: Since the horizontal components cancel out, the resultant force is purely vertical with magnitude F(1 + √3/2).
conclusion: The magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is F(1 + √3/2), or equivalently, F(1 + 0.866) ≈ 1.866F.
